content.webTitle: Beaming with pride: how Bob Hawke made it to one last special event

fields.headline: Beaming with pride: how Bob Hawke made it to one last special event
fields.bodyText: Bob Hawke didn’t live to see the result of the federal election but he did make it to one last special event. Last Saturday the former prime minister watched on as his beloved stepson, the artist Louis Pratt, married the former SBS television reporter Brianna Roberts at an intimate outdoor wedding at Mount Wilson in the Blue Mountains, west of Sydney. The ceremony was held in the Socrates Garden at Breenhold, where parts of The Great Gatsby film were filmed. The temperature was hovering around 13C but nothing could dampen Hawke’s spirits. He sat in a wheelchair, rugged up in a blanket and puffer jacket, next to his wife, Blanche d’Alpuget, in the front row. Despite the bitter cold Hawke’s face was beaming with pride for the couple. At their engagement party a year earlier in Sydney, he spent the afternoon on his balcony talking to guests, a Hawke Lager in one hand and a cigar in the other. Later he was in a singsong mood, leading the party in rousing renditions of Waltzing Matilda and Solidarity Forever. On Saturday he was too unwell to attend the wedding reception but many Hawke Lagers were consumed in his honour. Days later, when the couple returned to Sydney, they re-enacted their first dance for Hawke. Roberts had put back on her bridal gown and Pratt wore his tuxedo. “We did the dance in the living room for him. We danced to a recording of my dad [Geoff] playing piano and singing True Love. It was the last time we saw him. He was happy, serene, almost nostalgic. A very sweet farewell,” Roberts said. Pratt said his stepfather’s legacy would live on indefinitely. “He fought for the Australian people because he loved them and, as old age wearied him, there was only sweetness left,” he told Guardian Australia. “He loved fiercely and was a warrior to the end.” Pratt said he had regarded Hawke as a friend because he had been brought up by his father, Tony. But he had loved Hawke like a father, too. The couple said Hawke’s marital advice had been to enjoy themselves. “He was a true romantic,” Roberts said. The couple are expected to cut their overseas honeymoon short to return to Sydney for Hawke’s funeral.
